[ANALYSIS]: Logical review of prior note: 
• Causation vs. correlation – The earlier piece implied that a stronger Brazilian Real and lower Colombian output were ‘responsible’ for a single-day rebound. While plausible, intraday moves in coffee futures are multi-factor; the claim should be framed as correlation, not proven causation.
• Confirmation bias – The discussion emphasised bearish trend signals, then quickly neutralised them with one bullish data point (Colombia). A clearer separation of time-frames reduces the risk of cherry-picking.
• Vague sourcing – ‘Lower highs and lower lows dominate the structure’ was asserted without referencing a time window (e.g., since Oct-25). 
• Sentiment tag – Labelled ‘NEUTRAL’ despite conceding that the longer-term trend is still down. A split verdict (short-term neutral, medium-term bearish) would have been more transparent.

Revised view:
Trend: Since the Oct-25 high (382 ¢), KCK6 has fallen ≈ 23 %, printing successive lower highs (Jan-26 peak 335 ¢) and lower lows, confirming a primary down-trend. Price sits 14 % below its 200-day SMA and 6 % below the 50-day SMA (316.80 ¢), underscoring bearish control.
Momentum: The RSI at 28.69 signals a stretched move; the last four occasions the RSI dipped < 30 (Dec-23, Mar-24, Sep-24, Jun-25) were followed by 4-7 % bounces within two weeks. This does not negate the trend but warns of short-covering risk around 287-280 ¢ support.
Fundamentals: A 34 % y/y drop in January Colombian production removes ~170 k bags from export availability, but Colombia represents only ~9 % of global output; the impact is modest relative to Brazil’s 40 % share. Meanwhile, the Brazilian Real firmed 0.7 % versus the USD on 10 Feb, marginally reducing producer hedging incentive; yet the currency is still 4 % weaker than its 3-month average, limiting the bullish implication.
Levels: Key pivots—Support: 287.25 ¢ (50 % retracement of 2023-2025 rally) and 280.65 ¢ (Nov-24 low). A decisive break of 280.65 ¢ would open 270.00 ¢. Resistance: 295 ¢ initial; a daily close above 300 ¢ is required to question the down-trend and target the 50-day SMA at 316.80 ¢.
Bias: Primary trend remains bearish. However, oversold momentum and nearby structural support argue for caution in pressing new shorts; probability favours a short-term bounce toward 298-300 ¢ before sellers re-emerge. Longer-term (1-3 months) outlook stays negative unless 316.80 ¢ is reclaimed.
